translated: 13 Extensive Commentary on the Flower Ornament Sutra, ScrollğŸ”½
Fourteenth
Tang Dynasty Monk Chengguan of the Great Huayan Monastery on Mount Qingliang's Commentary
The general collection of the theories does not go beyond four views is the second general collection of the eleven into four theories, which is the meaning of the Bai Lun.
Within this there are two parts:
First, it correctly clarifies the theories; second, below If one theory, it clarifies the cause and effect. All are as extensive as the Bai Lun.
Although there are many differences is the third conclusion of the two causes.
It collects the eleven theories above, up to the ninety-five kinds, all of which do not go beyond the two causes:
Arising without a cause is called no cause;
The mistaken place of the theories is called a deviant cause.
For example, milk producing curd, milk is the correct cause;
Causing milk to produce a mat is a deviant cause.
Arising from the ignorance and karmic formations of this body is called the correct cause;
Arising from the primal nature and so forth are all deviant causes.

All dharmas arise from the convergence of conditions, and cease when conditions disperse. There is not a single dharma that does not arise from causes. Sentient and insentient realms all arise from causes. To say there are no causes is a great error.

It would mean that things should always arise without being produced, a barren woman should give birth to a child, tortoise hair should also produce things, and one should attain nirvÄá¹‡a without cultivating myriad practices. Then mundane and supramundane dharmas would all be destroyed at once. Therefore, the error of no cause is the greatest error.
The correspondences can be seen.

Apart from the Buddha's teachings, not only the ninety-five kinds, but even a thousand different theories, all fall into either wrong causes or no causes. Therefore, by teaching the one correct cause and condition, all theories are refuted.
The commentary below In this land, Confucianism and Daoism is the second part, describing this land.
The commentary is divided into two parts:
First, pointing out the same two causes; second, below Like Zhuangzi and Laozi, briefly presenting various theories.

However, the profound mysteries of Confucianism and Daoism in this land do not go beyond the three mysteries. The Book of Changes is the true mystery, Laozi is the empty mystery, and Zhuangzi is the discussed mystery.
Now the commentary has two parts:
First, it combines the quotations from Zhuangzi and Laozi, and then separately quotes the Book of Changes.
The first part is also divided into two:
First, quoting the text, and second, interpreting the meaning.
Now, the first part.
It quotes Laozi and Zhuangzi, therefore it says all believe in spontaneity.
This sentence is the heading.
Therefore, Zhuangzi says, Not knowing why it is so, it is called spontaneity.
It is said that people follow the earth... This is from the chapter on the Primordial State of Things in the Daodejing of Laozi.
This has the words There was something undifferentiated and yet complete, born before heaven and earth.
Silent and vast, it stands alone and does not change, it goes around and does not weary, it can be the mother of heaven and earth.
I do not know its name, so I provisionally call it the Way. It is forcefully named great, great is said to pass, passing is said to be far, far is said to return.
Therefore, the Way is great, Heaven is great, Earth is great, and the king is also great.
The commentary says, Based on what is great to illuminate it, the one who attains it is Heaven, Earth, and the king.
Heaven is great because it can cover, Earth is great because it can bear, and the king is great because he can emulate Earth, follow Heaven, and practice the Way, so it is said he is also great.
It also says, Within the realm, there are four great things, and the king occupies one of them.
The commentary says, The ruler is the lord of the human spirit, and the rise and fall of all things depend on him.
He is about to extend his admonitions and warnings, so it is said that the king occupies one.
He wants to alert the king to have something to emulate.
The next passage says, People emulate Earth, Earth emulates Heaven, Heaven emulates the Way, and the Way emulates naturalness.
The commentary says, People refer to the king.
To be a king, one should first emulate Earth and be stable and tranquil.
Having done so, you should also govern and generate things in accordance with the Way of Heaven.
Having generated things, you should also purify and act without doing anything in accordance with the Way, allowing things to transform themselves.
If a ruler can do this, then he will be in accord with the nature of the Way, the Dharma, and spontaneity.
The above commentary on the greatness of the Way says, Using 'pervasiveness' to express its virtue, it is called the Way. Using 'encompassing' to refer to its essence, it is forcefully named 'great'.
This passage is closely related, so it is fully cited. The intention is in the Way, the Dharma, and spontaneity.
The Treatise on Virtue also says, The Way gives birth to One, One gives birth to Two, Two gives birth to Three, and Three gives birth to the myriad things.
The previous [statement] deduces in reverse, while this [statement] argues in accordance with the sequence.
The commentary says, One refers to the primordial qi.
It says that the Way moves and gives birth to the profound, harmonious, and wondrous qi. In the principle of giving birth to things, it is not yet sufficient, and it further gives birth to yang qi.
Yang qi cannot give birth alone, and it further gives birth to yin qi.
Accumulating the qi of the Great Ultimate, it is said that one produces two. Accumulating the qi of yang, two produces three.

Yin and yang combine to conceive and nurture, and the qi of the Great Ultimate harmonizes and balances them, then the myriad things flourish and are accomplished, thus it is said that three produces the myriad things.
The next line also says, The myriad things rely on yin and embrace yang, and the qi of the Great Ultimate is used for harmony.
All of the above clarify that the myriad things are born naturally, which is the teaching of Laozi.
If you cite Zhuangzi, the Dazongshi Chapter of Zhuangzi says, The Way has feelings and faith, but is non-action and formless.
The annotation says, It has the feelings of having no feelings, so it is non-action.
It has the faith of having the constant nonexistence, so it is formless.
It also says, It can be transmitted but cannot be received.
The annotation says, It has been transmitted through the ages, but no one can receive and possess it.
It also says, It can be obtained but cannot be seen.
The commentary says: All can find their own place, yet none can see its form.
It also says: From the beginning, from the root, before heaven and earth existed, it has always been so.
The commentary says: It clarifies that non-existence does not depend on existence to be non-existence.
It also says: The spirits, the ghosts, the divine emperors, give birth to heaven and earth.
The commentary says: How can non-existence give birth to the spirits?
Without the spirits, ghosts, and emperors, the ghosts and emperors themselves become spiritual. This is the spirituality of non-spirituality.
Without giving birth to heaven and earth, heaven and earth themselves are born. This is the birth of non-birth.
Therefore, the fruit of the spirit is not enough to make it spiritual, but without spirituality, it is spiritual.
What merit is there to have, what affairs are there to rely on?

It also says: It is before the Great Ultimate, yet it is not lofty. It is below the six directions, yet it is not deep. It is born before heaven and earth, yet it is not old. It is longer than the ancient past, yet it is not old.
The commentary says, It means that the Way is present everywhere.
Therefore, being high is no high, being deep is no deep, being long is no long, being old is no old.
It is present everywhere, yet where it is present, it is nowhere.

It also says, Zhi Wei got it and held up heaven and earth, Fu Xi got it and succeeded the mother of qi, the Northern Dipper got it and never errs throughout the ages, the sun and moon got it and never cease throughout the ages, the potter got it and succeeded Kunlun, Feng Yi got it and roamed the great rivers, Jian Wu got it and dwelt in the great mountains, the Yellow Emperor got it and ascended to the clouds and heavens, and so on.
The commentary says, The Way has no ability.
This means that by getting it from the Way, it is used to illuminate its own attainment.ğŸ”½It also says, Knowing what heaven does and knowing what people do is the utmost.
The commentary says, Knowing what heaven and people do is all natural.

Then, internally releasing one's body and externally merging with things, one is in accord with the profound unity of all things, and by entrusting oneself to it, there is nothing that is not attained.
Then internally releasing one's body and externally merging with things, together with the myriad mysteries, entrusting to it and nothing is not attained. The meaning says:
But having knowledge of the conditioned, all are not acting while acting, therefore it is natural.
The commentary says If one takes naturalness as the cause and so on, this is the refutation.
It generally includes two positions. The first is the meaning of Laozi.
Because the Dao gives rise to one, the Dao is natural, therefore taking the Dao as its cause, this is a mistaken cause.
The commentary says If one says myriad things are naturally born and so on, this brings out the meaning of Zhuangzi.
Then myriad things are natural, without being made so, therefore it is said to be natural, which is no cause.
The commentary says Like the blackness of a crow and so on, this is the text of Zhuangzi, and also the meaning of the Nirvana Sutra.
The commentary says The Book of Changes says and so on, the second is citing the Book of Changes and so on. The text also has two parts:
First, citing the text, then interpreting the meaning.
Now, the first is the Appended Phrases.
Xi means to be connected to, and also means a network.
Here, the two characters si-fu (therefore) should be added at the beginning.
The commentary says, All existence must begin from non-existence, therefore the Great Ultimate gives rise to the two principles.
The Great Ultimate is a name for the nameless, it cannot be given a name.
Taking its utmost point of existence, it is likened to the Great Ultimate.
Kong said, The Great Ultimate, before Heaven and Earth were divided, was mixed into one, which is the Great Beginning and the Great One.
The Laozi says, 'The Dao gives rise to One,' which refers to this Great Ultimate.
When the Primordial Chaos divided, then there was Heaven and Earth, therefore it says the Great Ultimate gives rise to the two principles, which is the Laozi's 'One gives rise to Two.'
As for not mentioning Heaven and Earth, it refers to the material substance below, which corresponds to the Four Images, thus it says two instruments, meaning the two substances and forms.
The commentary says:
If we follow the Liezi, there are Taixia, Taiqiu, Taishi, and Taiç´ .
Taixia is when qi has not yet been seen.
Taiqiu is the beginning of qi.ğŸ”½Taishi is the beginning of form.
Taiç´  is the beginning of substance.
Their commentary says substance is nature.
It also explains:
Taixia refers to the Taiji of the Zhouyi. This means that Taiqiu is not Taixia, and Taiji is established at the beginning.
If we follow the explanation of the Yi Gouming Jue, there are five periods, the first four are the same as the Liezi, and the fifth is called Taiji, then Taiji is not the beginning.
The explanation is largely the same as the Liezi.
Period means the number of periods, and yi means to change.
When the primordial qi first disperses, it is called the Great Commencement.
When qi begins to take form, it is called the Great Beginning.ğŸ”½When form changes and takes substance, it is called the Great Undifferentiated.
When substance and form are complete, it is called the Great Ultimate.
Although there are slight differences, they all say that the primordial qi gives birth to Heaven and Earth.

The commentary says The two polarities give birth to the four images and so on. Confucius said, This refers to wood, metal, water, and fire receiving Heaven and Earth, so it is said that the two polarities give birth to the four images.
Earth divides and rules the four seasons.
Moreover, earth is a separate category, so there are only four images.
The four images give birth to the eight trigrams. This refers to Zhen (wood), Li (fire), Dui (metal), and Kan (water), each presiding over a season.
Moreover, Xun is the same as Zhen (wood), Qian is the same as Dui (metal), and adding Kun and Gen (earth) makes the eight trigrams.
The eight trigrams determine good and bad. Since the eight trigrams are established, the lines and images interact, and divination reveals good and bad, so good and bad are born.
As for great deeds, all matters have their own auspicious and inauspicious, and are vast and complete, thus able to give rise to the great affairs of the world.
The commentary states The Great Ultimate is the cause, etc. is the second point of interpretation.
It means that if one uses the Great Ultimate as the cause, then it is a belief in the existence of the non-existent, and also an erroneous cause.
The commentary states If it is said that the single yin, etc. comprehensively reveals erroneous causes and no causes.
The Book of Changes says One yin and one yang is called the Way, the unfathomable yin and yang is called the spirit.
As for One yin and one yang is called the Way, the commentary states What is the Way?
It is the name for non-existence.
There is nothing it does not penetrate, nothing it does not rely on, and it is referred to as the Way.
It is still and without substance, and cannot be made into an image.
When its function reaches its limit, the merit of non-existence becomes apparent, and thus it reaches the spirit with no fixed direction and the Changes with no substance, and the Way can be seen.
Therefore, by exhausting the changes to the utmost spirit, and using the spirit to clarify the Way,
Although yin and yang are different, there is no one to wait for them.ğŸ”½In yin, it is without yin, yin is born from it.
In yang, it is without yang, yang is formed from it.
Therefore, it is said that one yin and one yang is called the Way.
The commentary says (the commentary is not by Confucius, but by Kong Yingda):
One means non-existence, non-existence of yin and yang is called the Way.
The reason one is taken to be non-existent is because non-existence is empty non-existence, empty non-existence is the Great Ultimate.
It cannot be distinguished, it is only one, therefore, one is taken to be non-existent.
If there is an object, then there is each other forming a contrast, there are two and three, it cannot be one.
Therefore, when in yin, it is not seen as the function of yin, when in yang, it is not seen as the power of yang, yin and yang naturally exist.
Naturally, there is nothing to do, this is what is meant by the Way, therefore, it is called the Way.

In terms of number, it is called one; in terms of essence, it is called non-existence; in terms of the opening and penetration of things, it is called the Way; in terms of subtlety and inconceivability, it is called the spirit; in terms of responding to conditions and transformation, it is called the Yijing.
In summary, they are all referred to as emptiness and nothingness.
The sages use human affairs to name them, and establish their titles according to their meanings and principles.
The commentary states:
If it is said that the changes of yin and yang can give rise to myriad things, then this is a deviant cause.
Both the commentary and the subcommentary say that one means non-existence, so it is a cause of non-existence.
Therefore, it says that if one is considered to be empty nothingness, then it is also a cause of non-existence.
Since empty nothingness also encompasses deviant causes, it leads to the word also.
The subcommentary states: However, a cause of non-existence and a deviant cause... This is the third point, which concludes the errors by combining the two.
As for saying birth should always be birth, if people are naturally born, they should always be born as people, without needing parents and so forth.
The bodhi of sentient beings would also naturally arise, then all karmic retributions would not be attained through cultivation.
This is precisely the fault of having no cause.
If using emptiness as the cause, it is also the fault of a deviant cause.
Following the various theories, they are not mentioned in brief.
The above extensively refutes the various theories.
The commentary states: Because they do not know that the three realms arise from one's own mind... This is the third point, presenting the correct and refuting the deviant.
Within this, there are three parts:
First, generally clarifying the causes and conditions of delusion; second, elaborating on the profound meaning; third, distinguishing errors and revealing the deviant.

In the first part, the three realms arising from one's own mind is exclusively the teaching of the Mahayana, as seen in the Ten Grounds Sutra. The treatises on Consciousness-Only all cite this to establish their arguments.

It states that mental phenomena, in their own continuity, have flowed on and on since beginningless time, neither ceasing nor being permanent, relying on conditions and objects, neither qi nor endowment, only consciousness and only mind.
How can it be the same as Confucianism and Daoism, where qi transforms into the spirit, and the spirit is formed by qi, where qi is not formed by conditions, and arises from spontaneity?
Is it not that it is spontaneously formed, and its nature is transformed by itself, not by cultivation?
How much more so for the mind being separate from a mysterious nature or subtle particles, etc.?
How much more so for Brahma, etc., being the creator?
The commentary says from delusion there is craving, samsara is endless is from the Vimalakirti Sutra.
The meaning is common to both Mahayana and Hinayana. Mahayana has two meanings:
First, ignorance gives rise to karma, and craving can moisten karma;
Second, past ignorance and present craving and grasping.
Hinayana only has the latter meaning. Although it is caused by the three poisons, these two are superior.
The Nirvana Sutra also says that the original point of birth and death is generally of two kinds:
First, ignorance, second, craving for existence. In between these two, there is birth, old age, sickness, and death.
There are many such passages.

The Hinayana establishes the three poisons as the root of birth and death. The Zhonglun, in the chapter on the stained and the stain-possessor, says: The sutra says that greed, anger, and delusion are the root of the world, and so on, up to saying that the three poisons give rise to the three karmas, and the three karmas give rise to the three actions, and therefore there are all dharmas.

The chapter on the twelve links of dependent origination says: Sentient beings, covered by delusion, later create the three actions, and because of these actions, consciousness receives bodies in the six realms.
These all mean that the three poisons are the fundamental meaning.

However, although the non-Buddhists establish the three qualities, they do not know that they are what exists in their own minds, and they also consider them to arise from the unmanifest, and therefore they are considered to be wrong views.
The commentary says deluded about the correct causes and conditions, and so on. The mind of delusion and love is precisely the correct causes and conditions.

If the Mahayana teaches only mind as the cause and delusion and craving as the conditions, the Hinayana also takes delusion and craving as the cause and karma, etc. as the conditions, and the Mahayana also takes karmic seeds as the conditions.
The commentary says How can you know the emptiness of the nature of causes and conditions? This is the second point, which further brings out the profound meaning.
Even the shallow meaning of the characteristics of causes and conditions is still confused, let alone the limit of the truth of emptiness of nature.
The emptiness of nature is common to the initial sudden teaching and the final teaching, and the wondrous existence is precisely the true teaching.
If it is common to both emptiness and existence, the two texts intersect, and the complete virtues are precisely the perfect teaching.
The commentary says The words are mixed with below, the third point is to distinguish the errors and reveal the heterodox.
The Book of Changes says Still and unmoving, responding and thus penetrating the principles of the world.
The Book of Rites says When people are born, they are calm, which is the nature of Heaven.
Responding to things and moving is the desire of nature.
The Laozi says, It is profound and dark, yet within it there is essence. That essence is extremely true.
The Zhuangzi says, There is the true ruler abiding there.
In this way, later Confucians, because the words are slightly the same, without examining the original establishment before and after, they want to mix the three teachings.
Now in the present time, Master Cheng Yingzun composes commentaries on Zhuangzi and Laozi, extensively citing Buddhist teachings to compare with those classics.
But seeing that the words are slightly the same, how could they know that the meanings have great differences?
Later shallow-minded people are even more confused.
The commentary says it is the same as the parable of stealing a cow in the Nirvana Sutra, which is in the third chapter of the Nirvana Sutra, answering Kasyapa's question.
The sutra says, At that time Bodhisattva Kasyapa addressed the Buddha, saying:
'World-Honored One!
What are the differences between the teachings of the world and the teachings of the world-transcending?
As the Buddha has said:
The Buddha is the eternally abiding Dharma, the unchanging Dharma.
The world also says that Brahma Heaven is permanent, that the God of Sovereignty is permanent and unchanging, that the self is permanent, that nature is permanent, and that even dust is permanent.
If it is said that the TathÄgata is a permanent dharma,
why does the TathÄgata not always manifest?
If he does not always manifest, what is the difference?
Why is it so?
Because Brahma Heaven up to the nature of the world also does not manifest.
The Buddha told KÄÅ›yapa:

It is like a wealthy man who has many cows, although their colors are various they are all in one herd. He entrusts them to a cowherd to graze on water and grass, but only for the sake of ghee, not for the sake of milk or yogurt. That cowherd milks them and eats it himself.
When the wealthy man dies, all his cows are stolen by a group of bandits.
After the bandits obtain the cows, since they have no women, they themselves milk and eat them.
At that time, the group of bandits each said to each other:ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:
The great elder raises this cow not for milk or yogurt, but for ghee.
What method should we use to obtain it now?
Ghee is called the best flavor in the world.
We have no vessel, and even if we get milk, there is no place to store it.
They said to each other again:
Only a leather bag can be used to store it.
Although there is a storage place, they do not know how to churn it. It is difficult to even get whey, let alone fresh butter.
At that time, the thieves, for the sake of ghee, added water to it. Because there was too much water, the milk, yogurt, and ghee were all lost.
Ordinary people are also like this. Although they have good dharmas, they are all the remnants of the TathÄgata's true Dharma.
Why is it so?

After the TathÄgata, the World-Honored One, entered nirvÄá¹‡a, they secretly stole the remaining good dharmas of the TathÄgata, such as precepts, concentration, and wisdom, like those thieves plundering a herd of cows.
Although ordinary people may attain precepts, concentration, and wisdom, they lack skillful means and cannot explain them.
For this reason, they are unable to attain the constant precepts, constant concentration, constant wisdom, and liberation.
Just as that group of thieves did not know skillful means and lost the ghee, that group of thieves added water to the milk for the sake of ghee.

It is the same with ordinary people. For the sake of liberation, they speak of self, person, sentient being, life, human being, ordinary people, gods, MaheÅ›vara, atoms, primordial nature, precepts, concentration, wisdom, and liberation, and that the heaven of neither perception nor non-perception is nirvana. But they do not truly attain liberation and nirvana.
Just as that group of thieves did not obtain the ghee.

These ordinary people have a little pure conduct and make offerings to their parents. Because of these causes and conditions, they are reborn in the heavens and experience a little peace and joy, just like the milk mixed with water by that group of thieves.ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:

However, ordinary beings truly do not know that by cultivating a little pure conduct and making offerings to their parents, one can be reborn in the heavens. Moreover, they do not know about precepts, concentration, wisdom, and taking refuge in the Three Jewels. Because they do not know, they speak of permanence, bliss, self, and purity. Although they speak of it, they truly do not know.
Therefore, after the TathÄgata appears in the world, he expounds permanence, bliss, self, and purity.
It is like when a wheel-turning king appears in the world. By the power of his merit and virtue, the bandits retreat and the cows are not harmed.

At that time, the wheel-turning king entrusts the cows to a herdsman who is skilled in methods. This person uses skillful means to obtain ghee, and because of the ghee, all sentient beings are free from suffering and affliction.

When the Dharma Wheel Sage King appears in the world, ordinary beings who are unable to expound precepts, concentration, and wisdom immediately retreat and scatter, like bandits retreating and scattering.
At that time, the TathÄgata skillfully expounds the worldly and supramundane Dharma for the sake of sentient beings, and he causes the bodhisattvas to expound it accordingly.

Bodhisattva-mahÄsattvas, having obtained the finest essence, further enable immeasurable and boundless sentient beings to obtain the flavor of the unsurpassed nectar of the Dharma, namely the TathÄgata's permanence, bliss, self, and purity.
For this reason, good sons!
The TathÄgata is permanent and unchanging, unlike what ordinary foolish people in the world think, that BrahmÄ and others are permanent.
This term permanent must refer to the TathÄgata, not to other dharmas.
KÄÅ›yapa!
You should understand the TathÄgata's body in this way.
The commentary states:
The text comparing the Dharma to a metaphor can be understood.
This shows that the words of Confucianism and Daoism are the same, all coming from the Buddha's teachings.
The commentary states: What's more, squeezing donkey milk is the third passage in the Treatise on the Great Perfection of Wisdom.
The meaning is that Buddhist teachings are like cow's milk, and attaining liberation through cultivation is like squeezing out yogurt, fresh butter, and so on.
Without understanding cultivation, one cannot even obtain yogurt, let alone the teachings of non-Buddhists, which are like donkey milk.
The Buddha is likened to an ox, while non-Buddhists are like donkeys.
Donkey's milk is not a substance that can produce curd, and the teachings of non-Buddhists have no taste of liberation, so churning donkey's milk only results in feces and urine.
Practicing according to the teachings of non-Buddhists only leads to suffering and has no benefit.
The commentary states The various heterodox theories are explained in detail is the fourth point, indicating the brief summary.
Fearing it would be too verbose, it is abbreviated. In order to know the source, it only points out where it comes from.
The commentary states Now, I will only discuss is the fifth point, concluding the surpassing excellence.

As for the shallowest of the Buddha's teachings, it is because the ten schools become increasingly profound from front to back, and increasingly deep from back to front. Compared to the tenth school, the first two schools are eight times deeper. They are already able to comprehensively refute all non-Buddhist teachings, let alone the third school, the fourth school, and so on up to the tenth school, which become increasingly profound and wonderful.

However, all the above are profound and mysterious teachings of non-Buddhist schools. Now, the second [teaching] can surpass them all, so it is said that the shallowest of the Buddhist teachings is already superior to the deepest of the non-Buddhist teachings.

However, the non-Buddhist teachings of the West clearly speak of the three periods of time, mostly believe in cause and effect, know to detest birth and death, and joyfully seek nirvana. But because the true source differs slightly, it leads to a great distance from the Way.
Moreover, the Confucianism and Daoism of this land are only good for one lifetime. Even if there is a lifetime of mourning, there is no concern for the afterlife.
Although they equate birth and death, and strongly emphasize withering and flourishing, they consider birth and death to be determined by Heaven, and withering and flourishing to be subject to fate.
Heaven is the principle of naturalness, and fate is the reception ofè™›ç„¡. The gathering and dispersing of qi is birth and death, and returning to nothingness is the ultimate Way.
Compared to Buddhism, they are not even in the same year.
Briefly distinguishing the differences between Buddhism and Daoism, with ten points of difference.
First, the difference between beginninglessness and having a beginning.
It means that the explanation of the causes and conditions of arising and ceasing has no definite beginning.
Confucianism and Daoism have the Great Beginning and the Great Commencement, which are prior to things.
The Great Beginning is prior to the myriad things, and things create themselves.
Causes and conditions are the basis of the myriad dharmas, and their arising and ceasing depend on people.
The two qi are different from non-qi.
The explanation takes the mind as the basis of dharmas, and myriad practices rely on conditions.
The Dao takes the transformation of qi to be the spirit, and non-action transforms itself.
If it transforms itself, then there is no cultivation and no practice, abandoning wisdom and transcending the sage;
Relying on conditions necessarily requires cultivation and accomplishment, and myriad practices converge on the basis.
Third, the difference between the three time periods and the non-three time periods.
The explanation takes the substance of form and mind, the spiritual connection, following conditions to arise and cease, and the three time periods to flow.
Confucianism and Daoism take the gathering of qi to be birth, and the dispersal of qi to be death. When dead, it returns to Heaven and Earth, not continuing and not remaining.
Since it ends with one body, how can it know the three time periods?
Fourth, the difference between habitual and non-habitual.

The Buddhist teaching says that good and evil are due to karma, and foolishness and wisdom are cultivated from birth. Therefore, through accumulating eons of cultivation, the spiritual consciousness becomes profound and subtle.

The Confucian and Daoist teachings say that good and evil are due to distinctions, and foolishness and wisdom are innate. If one receives pure harmony, one becomes the most sage and most spiritual; if one receives turbid mixture, one becomes foolish and ignorant.
Even if they say to be cautious in learning, it only pertains to one's own body. How can they speak of accumulating abilities to benefit future lives?
Fifth, the difference in receiving conditions and receiving qi.
The Buddhist teaching says that the myriad phenomena are all born from conditions.
The Confucian and Daoist teachings say that wealth, nobility, good fortune, and misfortune are all due to qi and fate.
Those who receive qi cannot be changed, but those who receive conditions can be increased and cultivated.
Sixth, the difference between internal and non-internal.
The Buddhist teaching says that the myriad things in the world are born from the transformation of internal consciousness.
The Confucian and Daoist teachings say that humans, things, worms, and flying insects are all transformed by Heaven and Earth.
If it is within me, I can transform and purify it. If it is transformed by Heaven, I will let it be high or low.
The Buddha explains that the four characteristics of change and flow, floating and illusory, and transformation and destruction, are all due to the power of conditions, not natural.
Confucianism and Daoism consider the daily changes and monthly shifts to be new and different, and the power is all natural, not due to one's mind.
The eight heavens are different from the heavens.
Confucianism and Daoism divide misfortune, blessings, good and bad into two:
First, heaven, second, earth.
What is done on earth can be blocked and cut off, so schemes are scattered and fragile before they are conceived;
What is done by heaven cannot be escaped, so one receives it with joy and forgets it and returns to it.
Therefore, those who rely on heaven abandon human affairs, cut off from the sages and follow the Dao. This is the meaning of Laozi.
The Buddha explains that the source of karmic retribution and causes and conditions is twofold:
First, suffering and its causes, second, cessation and the path.
Cessation and the path do not abide in or cling to, are free from annihilation and permanence, rise above the extremes of emptiness and existence, and transcend birth and death.
As for suffering and its cause, they arise from the turning of the mind, following karma, high and low, coming and going in the six destinies, lingering within the three realms.
Therefore, those who are weary of suffering eliminate its cause, and those who delight in cessation cultivate the path. This is the essence of Buddhism.
The principles of the two schools are as clear as in the palm of one's hand.
The doors are thousands, with different returns and distinct principles. Compared to the one, how can it be obtained?
Nine, the difference between defilement and non-defilement.
Laozi destroys benevolence with the Way, and when benevolence is cut off, the Way naturally stops, it does not lie in action.
Desire harms the nature, and when desire is removed, the nature is naturally attained, it does not lie in cultivation.
Profit burdens life, and when profit is screened, life naturally becomes complete, it does not lie in benefit.
Ritual arises from chaos, and when ritual is abandoned, chaos naturally disappears, it does not lie in creation.
Reason relies on the Way, and when there is the Way, reason naturally arrives, it does not lie in the sage.
When one attains it at the right time, the position is naturally accomplished when the time comes, not by contention.
Therefore, what is not sought is naturally attained, what is not done is naturally accomplished;
what is done will surely fail, what is sought will surely be lost - this is the teaching of Laozi.
The Buddha takes goodness as the foundation of the path of blessings, cultivating goodness and receiving blessings in the human and heavenly realms;
evil is the root of the path of evil, accumulating evil and sinking into the three evil realms.
Compassion is the path of non-harming, desire is the source of birth and death. Cutting off desire will surely end birth and death, practicing compassion will lead to a long life.
Therefore, those who do good will surely attain it, those who do evil will surely lose it;
those who are free from desire will surely transcend desire, those who are not free from desire will surely fall into desire - this is the teaching of Shakyamuni.
The methods of teaching are already distinguished, and the differences are clear.
It is like comparing cold and warmth, the principles are difficult to combine.
The ten returns are different from non-returns.
The Buddha explained that the suffering of birth and death comes from delusion and takes form.
Craving and attachment arise from ignorance.
If they arise from ignorance, they can be cut off and removed.
If they come from delusion, they can be plucked out and eradicated.
Plucking out and eradicating is based on the provisional nature of existence, while cutting off is based on the falsity of the substance.
Those who know the falsity of the substance will cease delusion and realize nirvana;
Those who understand the provisional nature of existence will abandon the provisional and return to quiescence.

Thus, controlling the One Vehicle and floating on the six perfections, they cross the sea of suffering of birth and death and escape the burning house of afflictions, soaring to the terrace of prajna and wondrously entering the garden of nirvana, eternally blissful and coexisting with space, lofty and wondrously illuminated, with the realm and wisdom both quiescent. This is the ultimate goal of Buddhism.
Laozi said that life and death are fate, all due to the workings of the Dao.
Sagehood and mediocrity are nature, simply bestowed by Heaven.
Heaven and man cannot escape, and the Way cannot be resisted.
Those who know that the Way of Heaven cannot be deluded or resisted can peacefully abide in birth and death and preserve the completeness of their nature and emotions.

When nature and emotions are complete, Heaven does not destroy them. When birth and death are abided in, the Way is not diminished. When the Way is not diminished, the thoughts of delight and aversion disappear. When Heaven is not destroyed, the mind of joy and anger ceases. Thus, one leaves the realm of worldly dust and wanders in the land of morality and virtue. One governs the solitary loftiness within the world and the spirit alone concentrates outside the square. Tranquil and mysterious, the myriad harms cannot reach. Fearless and effortless, the deviant qi cannot invade. One can attain longevity and live out one's years. This is the ultimate goal of Laozi's teachings.
Since the ultimate goals are different, the starting points are also distinct. The distance between them is vast, a thousand miles is not far.
These above ten differences, I hope you will carefully consider and ponder deeply.

They mostly use the causes and conditions of the Lesser Vehicle to refute the profound and wondrous of other schools, let alone the wondrous matter and principle of ultimate emptiness, the all-encompassing of defilement and purity, the unobstructed oneness and multiplicity, and the interreflection of layers upon layers, and the perfect interfusion of every thought?
Do not seek a small name for a moment, but rather unify the three teachings;
Cultivate the poisonous seeds of wrong views, and create the deep causes for hell;
Open the source and flow of ignorance, and block the mysterious path of universal wisdom.
Warn! Warn!
Those who transmit and teach should carefully select.

The Beijing scholar Su said:
Because of the above meaning, the Dharma Treasury of the Four Part Vinaya is the meaning of the Dharmaguptaka.

The commentary states The fourth school that distinguishes the real and provisional in the present includes one complete and one partial school.
The one complete school is the SautrÄntika school.
The one partial school is the later SautrÄntika school, because the original SautrÄntika school is included in the first school.

The Satyasiddhi ÅšÄstra was originally composed by a SÄá¹ƒkhya disciple who regarded the created as the creator. Later, when he left home and entered the Buddha's teachings, he was included in the SautrÄntika school.
Therefore, the Tripiá¹­aka master said:

The SautrÄntika school distinguishes the real and provisional in the present, and the meaning of real and provisional is the same, so it is included in the school that distinguishes the real and provisional in the present.
This refers to the school that distinguishes the real and provisional, which is different from the EkavyÄvahÄrika school and the LokottaravÄda school.
This means that within reality, there is the real and the provisional. The meaning explained in terms of the aggregates is real, because it is a real accumulation;
the meaning explained in terms of the bases and elements is provisional, because it is a provisional accumulation.
Now, the commentary says the Satyasiddhi ÅšÄstra is a small part of the later SautrÄntika school.
The commentary says the sixth is the school of the truth of false worldly convention and so on, because the worldly is provisional, and because of being provisional it is false.
The supramundane is true, and truth is not provisional, so it is real.
It is slightly similar to the MÅ«lamadhyamakakÄrikÄ, with half preceding it.
The commentary says the seventh is the school of the names of all dharmas, which means that even the supramundane is a provisional name.

Therefore it says all selves and dharmas are also like the MÅ«lamadhyamakakÄrikÄ. If there is the worldly, then there is the supramundane. Since there is no worldly, how can there be a supramundane? and so on.ğŸ”½The commentary says the eighth is the school of the emptiness and transcendence of characteristics of true emptiness, which is the school of the principle of perfect reality established by the MahÄyÄna masters.

The commentary says the ninth is the school of the emptiness of both ultimate and conventional truths, which is the school of the emptiness of both ultimate and conventional truths established by the MahÄyÄna masters.

The treatise says The ninth is the school of the unobstructed interfusion of existence and non-existence. This means that because they mutually interpenetrate, existence is existence that is emptiness, and emptiness is emptiness that is existence. Speaking of emptiness must include existence, and speaking of existence must include emptiness. Therefore, it is said that they mutually interpenetrate.
Both are utterly negated means that because existence is emptiness, existence is negated, and because emptiness is existence, emptiness is negated.

It is said that they are not obstructed, and both are preserved because the characteristics are not destroyed. Existence is emptiness, but existence is not obliterated. Emptiness is existence, but emptiness is not lost.

Suchness following conditions means that the above statement about the interfusion of existence and emptiness may be confused with mere emptiness, so it is said that suchness is emptiness, and emptiness is suchness.
Moreover, it is different from mere stillness, so it is said to follow conditions, but it is not without immutability.
Endowed with the merits of the Ganges sands means that only the school of the nature of dharmas, and not merely empty quiescence.
The above are all the meanings within the true teaching, as explained in the section on establishing the teachings.
The tenth, the tenet of perfect interfusion and endowment of virtues is extensively discussed in the section on doctrinal classification.
The passage However, these ten tenets are deeper in the later ones than in the earlier ones is the third part of the commentary, which analyzes and distinguishes.
Within this, there are two parts:
First, a general analysis and distinction of the ten tenets; second, resolving difficulties and reconciling contradictions.
The first part has five points:
First, a general discussion of shallow and deep, thus the later ones are deeper than the earlier ones.
However, the first six of these ten tenets are completely the same as the great master of the Mahayana teachings.

The Mahayana has eight tenets, the seventh is called the ultimate emptiness of both, and the eighth is called the principle of perfect reality. It takes the characteristics of dharmas as the principle of perfect reality, and the nature of dharmas as the ultimate emptiness of both.

Now, the seventh is turned into the eighth, and the eighth is turned into the seventh. As mentioned before, there were two different schools in the Western Regions. Now, in accordance with the nature of dharmas, two more are added to show the profundity.
The passage The first four are only Hinayana, the fifth and sixth are common to both Mahayana and Hinayana is the second part of the analysis and distinction of Mahayana and Hinayana.
However, the fifth and sixth are established in the HÄ«nayÄna, and their meaning is common to the MahÄyÄna, therefore it says the fifth and sixth are common to the Great and Lesser Vehicles.

The first school's two truths both exist, which can be understood.
The commentary's Like the verses in the palm refers to the treatise composed by the Bodhisattva Clear Discrimination, which only explains this verse in one treatise.
There are two levels of inference here:
The first half is the inference of conditioned phenomena.
It is said that the established dharma is that conditioned phenomena are existent, and the property of the thesis is definitely empty and without nature.
The reason is because they arise from conditions.
The similar example is like illusory phenomena.ğŸ”½Illusory phenomena arise from conditions, and illusory phenomena are empty and without nature.
Conditioned phenomena arise from conditions, and conditioned phenomena are empty and without nature.
Here, the reason and example are reversed, or perhaps the text is incomplete.
As for true nature, it refers to the nature of conditioned phenomena, and should also say the true nature of conditioned phenomena is empty.
Second, the inference about unconditioned phenomena.
It is said that unconditioned phenomena are the established dharma, and the property of the thesis is definitely because they are unreal.
The reason is because they do not arise.
The similar example is like a sky flower.
A sky flower has no arising, and a sky flower has no reality;
Unconditioned phenomena have no arising, and unconditioned phenomena also have no reality.
Therefore, the Madhyamaka-Å›Ästra says: If there are conditioned phenomena, then there are unconditioned phenomena.
Since there are no conditioned phenomena, how can there be unconditioned phenomena?
As extensively discussed in that treatise.

The commentary states: It is a part of the meaning in the PrajÃ±ÄpÄramitÄ and Three Treatises. This is because in the Three Treatises, before the chapter on the Four Truths, emptiness is used to eliminate existence, and in the chapter on the Four Truths, emptiness is used to establish existence.
Therefore, a verse says: Because of the meaning of emptiness, all dharmas can be established.
If there were no meaning of emptiness, then everything would not be established.
Moreover, the title is named Madhyamaka Treatise, intending to show non-attachment to emptiness and existence, not just clarifying emptiness.
Moreover, a verse says: The dharmas produced by causes and conditions, I say are precisely emptiness, also called provisional names, also called the meaning of the middle way.
Then the three contemplations are equally driven, and the three truths are unobstructed. How can it be only emptiness?
Therefore, some say that those who study NÄgÄrjuna's teachings and fall into the evil destinies are empty. These words are frightening.
Therefore, it is said to be a part of the meaning, which is the meaning of the contemplation of emptiness, one of the three contemplations.

The ninth tenet of the two truths being unobstructed means that the true does not obstruct the conventional, and the conventional does not obstruct the true. The two truths are always distinct from each other, but in understanding they are always one.
Penetrating this non-duality truly enters the ultimate truth.
The two truths are both non-dual, always in conflict, never separate - this is also the meaning.
Now, I will briefly point out the previous text.
The reason why the tenth tenet is not discussed is that the tenth can also be called the inexhaustible tenet of the two truths.
However, it must be integrated with the previous, so it is not established separately.
Moreover, the first three tenets are established by various masters, so they are described here.
The tenth tenet is not disputed by them, so it is not mentioned.
The commentary states, However, the ten tenets and five teachings... This is the second explanation to address difficulties.
There are those who raise questions, saying:
How are the ten tenets different from the five teachings, yet they are repeatedly discussed?
Therefore, this is the explanation.
However, there are two meanings:
First, the general and specific are different, second, the substance and style are different.
Now, first, the two are listed together;
later, under the teaching then, the two are explained together, clarifying the two general principles and implicitly showing the two specific principles.
The upper sentence says the teaching then, one sutra may contain many teachings, which clarifies the general principle of the teaching.

For example, a single Vimalakirti Sutra contains the five teachings, and the Nirvana Sutra, Prajnaparamita Sutra, etc. also contain the five teachings, thus implicitly showing the specific principle of the school.
The Vimalakirti Sutra is only the principle of the unobstructedness of phenomena and principle, and does not include the principle of the three natures, emptiness, existence, etc.
The phrase the school then, the school may contain many sutras clarifies the general principle of the school.

Because within a single principle of the unobstructedness of phenomena and principle, it includes the Lotus Sutra, Vimalakirti Sutra, Nirvana Sutra, etc., thus implicitly showing the specific principle of the teaching.
For example, within a single sutra, there are the five teachings, and they do not mutually include each other.
The commentary states Moreover, in establishing teachings, one must have the understanding and realization and so on, which is the second point, clarifying the differences in the framework.
It also comprehensively responds to objections again.
The objection states:
If each has its own scope, why can't the main purport be taken as the teaching, and the teaching be taken as the main purport?
Therefore, this is the response.
The teachings have distinctions in the stages of understanding and realization, and therefore there are only five main purports.
Based on the different things that are valued, there are ten main purports.

Therefore, the first six have different things that are valued and form six main purports, but the understanding and realization, etc. are the same, and are only the Lesser Vehicle teaching, so there is no contradiction between the teaching and the main purport.
The commentary states The second is to reveal the specific main purport and below, which is the second explanation of the specific main purport.
The commentary is divided into two parts:
First, generally clarifying the intention of establishing; second, opening up the chapters and explaining separately.
Now, there are two parts to the first:
First, it is correctly established that each sÅ«tra has its own main purport, and therefore this specifically clarifies the main purport of this sÅ«tra.
As the Lotus Sutra takes the One Vehicle as its main theme, and the Nirvana Sutra takes the Buddha-nature's permanence, etc. as its main theme, it is said that each has its own main theme.
Although there is mutual inclusion, based on their biased emphasis, they are designated as separate main themes.
The commentary below However, in the Laá¹…kÄvatÄra SÅ«tra explains the difficulties.
The difficulty is:
The second chapter of the Laá¹…kÄvatÄra SÅ«tra says, Great Wisdom!
All dharmas are unborn, and one should not establish this as a main theme.
Therefore, the present explanation says:
These words only dispel attachments.
If one does not establish a main theme in any way, why did they establish the main theme and explain the main theme?
Therefore, the sÅ«tra says, The main theme is for one's own practice, and the explanation is for showing those who are not yet enlightened.
An ancient person said:
If the main theme is understood but the explanation is not, it is like the sun being obscured by clouds.
If both the main theme and the explanation are understood, it is like the sun in the empty sky.
Since there are two understandings, it is not that there is no main theme.
This is the principle of no principle, established yet non-established, serving as the principle for comprehensive explanation, this is the sun dwelling in the sky.
The commentary states Briefly distinguished by two approaches below, the second is to open up the chapters and explain separately.
Within this, there are also two parts:
First, listing the chapters; second, The first below, explaining separately according to the chapters.

This is the verse of the heavenly king of the ocean of wondrous flames in the present sutra, which states The Buddha's body pervades all great assemblies, filling the Dharma realm without end and so forth.

The commentary states Because the characteristics of dependent origination mutually enter each other is the meaning of the approach of the characteristics of dependent origination mutually relying on each other.
The commentary states Before the ten sages below, in this one teacher's commentary, there are two parts:
First, presenting the meaning and establishing it in general;
Later, below The former two masters is the explanation, which explains the words mutual deficiency and brings out the intention of the new establishment.
Within this, there are two parts:
First, bringing out the mutual deficiency; later, below Therefore, the intention of the Wise and Foremost One, showing the basis for the establishment.
Although relying on Master Guangtong, it is further added.

First, a general indication;

First, generally clarifying the reason, because he obtained the specific but lacked the general.
Below Because of the dharmadhÄtu, second, bringing out the characteristics of the general and specific.
The dharmadhÄtu has four aspects, the principle is truly one, therefore it is said to be specific.
Dependent arising is general, but has two meanings:
First, the originally existent dependent arising, like the vast and extensive.
Fangguang is the function, and Zhoubian is the inherent nature.
Fo huayan is the cause and effect, which is the conditioned arising of cultivation and accomplishment.
Moreover, conditioned arising is the meaning, and cause and effect is the stage.
The second part of the commentary, below expounding the present understanding, has two parts:
First, generally clarifying the establishment; second, below explaining the previous meaning, opening up the chapter and explaining separately.
There are five parts in the former:

First, generally indicating the establishment; second, revealing its inclusion; third, showing the reason for the addition; fourth, explaining and passing through difficulties; fifth, repeatedly revealing the different aspects.
First, the meaning is as follows:
Briefly, the tenth teacher has many words.
Since the Guangtong branch does not include the general, it should be said that the Dharma realm is conditioned arising.
The general includes the specific, and the words cause and effect, principle and reality should not be retained.

If taking the extensive explanation, it also lacks the inconceivable, therefore it is said that if taking the previous meaning, it should be said that the cause and effect conditioned arising, the principle and reality Dharma realm, and the inconceivable are the main points.
If we take the order, we should say that the principle of the Dharma realm is the cause and effect of dependent origination, the inconceivable as the main point.
The second is the explanation of its inclusion, below the passage This then includes the general title.
The character fang is used twice. Looking up, it is the great square, because the great square has no corners and is the Dharma realm.
Looking down, it is the broad square, because the function is the Dharma realm of dependent origination.
Therefore, it is said that the Dharma realm completely includes the previous two.
The third is the explanation of the reason for adding the inconceivable, below the passage The words such as Dharma realm.
It distinguishes from other sÅ«tras, therefore it also quotes the text to prove it.
The fourth is the explanation of the difficult point, below the passage The VimalakÄ«rti SÅ«tra only clarifies.
If it adds the inconceivable in order to distinguish from other sÅ«tras, it is still the same as the VimalakÄ«rti SÅ«tra, how can it be distinguished?
Therefore, this is the explanation.
They obtain the function, but not the virtue and characteristics, therefore.
Therefore, that sÅ«tra says, There is liberation called inconceivable.
Bodhisattvas dwelling in this liberation can place the height and breadth of Mount Sumeru inside a mustard seed.

It never says that true suchness possesses inexhaustible virtues, that the Buddha's body is not divided yet pervades the virtues of dust and hair, and that those virtues are inexhaustible, etc., so they are only a part of it.
Therefore NÄgÃ¢rjuna calls this sÅ«tra the Great Inconceivable SÅ«tra, which shows that the other is the Lesser Inconceivable.
Although the inconceivable is without size, in the teachings it is manifested as having breadth and narrowness.
The commentary's If we discuss it in terms of the title is the fifth layer of revealing a different approach.

What has been explained above only clarifies that the sÅ«tra's purport is already complete within the title. If we follow Tiantai Zhizhe's explanation of the Lotus SÅ«tra, within a single title there is essence, purport, and function.
Now we take this as an analogy to explain, so there are three.

As for mutually using both, all are unobstructed, it means that if the characteristics of the natures are not destroyed, then it is the principle dharma realm, and the meaning of nature is called realm.
If it is the phenomena dharma realm, the meaning of division is called realm.
If the characteristics and natures interpenetrate, then since the characteristics are precisely the nature, the division is precisely called nature, and the nature is precisely the characteristics.
There is no division that is not a division, therefore it is said that they mutually penetrate.
The commentary states: The second reveals the meaning, which has four aspects. There are three parts to this aspect:
First, a general introduction; second, a specific explanation; third, a concluding summary.
The first introduction can be understood.
The specific explanation of the four chapters is divided into four parts.
The commentary states: The first is the specific opening of the dharma realm, and so on. This section of commentary has four parts:
First, introducing the chapter and briefly explaining;
Second, below Among them, the ten matters, opening the chapter and specifically explaining.
Third, As for this cause and effect, they mutually serve as the purport, reconciling the purport.
However, there are two meanings:
First, the five periods all take cause and effect as their main theme.
If cultivation is taken as the main theme, attaining the effect is the goal;
taking the effect as the main theme, it is for the sake of cultivating the cause.
Second, the cause and effect that are believed in are the main theme, and attaining the differentiated cause and effect is the goal;
taking the differentiation as the main theme, it is for the sake of what is believed;ğŸ”½taking the differentiation as the main theme, it is for the sake of attaining equality;
taking equality as the main theme, it is for the sake of harmonizing the differentiation;ğŸ”½taking equality as the main theme, it is for the sake of accomplishing practice;

taking the accomplishment of all practices as the main theme, it is for the sake of believing in equality;ğŸ”½taking the accomplishment of practice as the main theme, it is for the sake of realization;
taking realization as the main theme, it is for the sake of forgetting realization and cultivating practice.
Therefore, it is said mutually.
The passage from beginning to end of a sutra is the fourth point, concluding cause and effect.
It includes the meanings of the previous four teachers, the fifth, sixth, seventh, and eighth, because they all do not go beyond cause and effect.
Therefore, this cause and effect do not contradict the Dharma realm, because it is by means of the Dharma realm that cause and effect are established.
The commentary below the line The second is the mutual inclusion of cause and effect, which is the same as the Dharma realm also has four parts:
First, stating the chapter;
Second, below the line Within the Dharma realm gate, opening up the chapter and explaining it;
Third, below the line The five pairs are specifically clarified, reconciling the six explanations, namely, because cause and effect are not destroyed and mutually penetrate;
Fourth, below the line The above five periods of cause and effect, concluding and returning to the Dharma realm, gathering the previous two masters, Yan and Yu.
Within the conclusion and return to the Dharma realm, there are two meanings. First, returning to the Dharma realm of phenomena and principle.
That is, the fifth cause and effect is the previous cause and effect.
Moreover, the first four pairs are all common to cause and effect, because both cause and effect have objects, wisdom, etc.
Moreover, within the third pair, one kind is principle, and the remaining nine kinds of phenomena are all phenomena. Therefore, the five periods of cause and effect are not beyond these ten.
Second, how much more so for the naturelessness of cause and effect, below, it unifies the above into the Dharma realm of principle.
The commentary states: Third, the causes and effects of the Dharma realm are clearly revealed, the text also has four parts:
First, a general statement;
Second, there are also ten meanings below, a specific explanation;

Third, the above five pairs below, unifying the purport, such as taking the Dharma realm in entanglements as the purport, and causing the liberation from entanglements and purity as the goal, the other four can be understood by analogy;
Fourth, among the above five below, concluding and demonstrating the characteristics of the causes and effects of the Dharma realm, and collecting the previous Guangtong teacher.
Only the first pair is the principle and reality of the Dharma realm, the rest are all the causes and effects of dependent origination.
The commentary states: Fourth, the causes and effects of the Dharma realm are both fused, this gate only has two parts:
First, a preliminary statement; second, a specific explanation.
Now, the first.
Because they are both fused, they are both absent; because they are both fused, they are indistinct.
Absence does not obstruct existence, therefore it is called unobstructed.
Able to preserve and able to detach, therefore it is said to be autonomous.
Although the Dharma realm generally includes both phenomena and principle, now it takes principle as real, therefore the Dharma realm is the nature, and cause and effect are the characteristics.

The commentary's First, due to detachment from characteristics and below, in the specific explanation, the first two pairs only clarify both detachments, the third and fourth pairs do not obstruct both presences.
However, the nature is indestructible, only saying it is not obliterated.
The characteristics can be destroyed, therefore it says they are not destroyed.
The fifth combines the first two, and the sixth combines the fourth and third, all because the nature and characteristics mutually include each other, therefore the two pairs are not different.
The seventh again combines the fifth and sixth, that is, the sixth is presence, and the fifth is obliteration, correctly present and immediately obliterated, therefore again not different.
The eighth melts the previous cause and effect, causing them to be the same as the Dharma realm.
The ninth is due to the mutual inclusion of cause and effect being the same as the Dharma realm.
The tenth is causing the discriminated dharmas of cause and effect to each individually include.
Having already understood the general meaning, next, following the difficulties, explain.

The commentary states this is taking characteristics as the main point and so on. The intention of bringing up characteristics is to cause one to transcend them, because one should not dwell on characteristics.
Later, it combines with the above transcendence of characteristics, both of which are taken as the main point.
Causing one to transcend cause and effect means that previously, in transcending characteristics, the characteristics of cause and effect were clarified as originally transcendent;
Now, in transcending cause and effect, it causes one to transcend the mind that grasps at characteristics.
As for saying the following nine can be understood by analogy, in the second one, it should be said that taking nature as the main point causes one to transcend nature as the goal;
Transcending nature as the main point causes one to transcend the dharma realm as the goal.
In the third one, transcending nature is taken as the main point, and not obliterating nature is taken as the goal, because nature is originally self-transcendent and does not depend on obliteration.
Moreover, transcending nature and not obliterating nature is taken as the main point, and causing one to transcend the dharma realm without obstructing the dharma realm is taken as the goal.

In the fourth one, transcending characteristics is taken as the main point, and not destroying characteristics is taken as the goal, because characteristics are originally self-transcendent and do not depend on destruction.

Moreover, transcending characteristics and not destroying characteristics is taken as the main point, and causing one to transcend cause and effect without destroying cause and effect is taken as the goal.
Fifth, the principle of transcending characteristics is the same as the principle of transcending nature, because nature and characteristics are not different.
If they were different from transcending nature, they would not be true transcendence of characteristics.
Moreover, the principle of transcending characteristics being the same as transcending nature is to make both nature and characteristics merge and disappear.
Sixth, the principle of the indestructible characteristics is the same as the principle of the indestructible nature.
If one were to separate the indestructible from the indestructible, it would be definitely existent.
Moreover, the principle of the indestructible being the same as the indestructible is to make both exist and manifest.
Seventh, the principle of both existence and non-existence is the same as the principle of both disappearance and non-disappearance, because existence is only possible when there is disappearance.

Moreover, the principle of both existence and non-existence being the same as both disappearance and non-disappearance is to make both transcend sight and hearing and transcend thought without obstructing seeing, hearing, speaking, and thinking.
However, the wonderful Dharma that transcends sight and hearing is spoken in terms of characteristics;
the profound meaning that transcends thought is spoken in terms of nature.

The eighth principle is the fusion of the eight realms of phenomena, which cannot be divided, leading to the goal of each cause and effect encompassing the eight realms of phenomena.ğŸ”½The ninth principle is each cause and effect completely encompassing the eight realms of phenomena, leading to the goal of cause and effect mutually existing.
The twelfth principle is the differentiation of the twelve stages all encompassing the eight realms of phenomena, leading to the goal of each stage of practice being inexhaustible.
The commentary states, The above four approaches is the third overall conclusion.
Within this, there are four parts:
First, using essence and function to include them. The essence is the previous nature, and the function is the previous characteristics.
Second, The first is the cause and effect and below, using the eleven characters in the principle to include them.
Third, Since the fourth melts the previous, the four approaches are the same overall melts the four approaches.

Fourth, Therefore, it is illumination and below, reconciling and returning to the mind's contemplation. In the Dharma, it is separation. In the mind, it is obstruction. In the Dharma, it is indestructible. In the mind, it is illumination.
Obstruction is the first two approaches, and illumination is the last two approaches.
However, the first negation is the negation that is illumination, and the second illumination is the illumination that is negation.
The fifth is the double negation.
The sixth is the double illumination.
The seventh is the correct double negation and the correct double illumination.
The eighth is the four gates being the same, the perfect and bright single contemplation.
The ninth and tenth each contain the previous four within a single phrase, and are also the same contemplation.
Moreover, the simultaneous illumination of the ten gates is illumination, and the absence of mind towards the ten is negation.

The double illumination illuminates the previous illumination and negation, and the double negation negates the previous negation and illumination. Words are forgotten and thoughts cease, yet it is clearly and distinctly understood.
Therefore, the ten gates are perfectly clear and bright in a single contemplation, and only then do they accord with the meaning of the ten gates.
They combine the essence of the previous four gates, and I hope you will understand this point.ğŸ”½Here is the corrected and aligned text:
Dafangguang fo huayan jing suishou yanyi chao, scroll 14
